guides.title: CPR for Adults

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey
Assess responsiveness
If there is no response, call for medical help (use speaker-phone if on a mobile) and send someone for an AED
steps.warning: If you are alone and have no phone, go for help and an AED if available

steps.instruction: Perform a primary survey
steps.detail: Open the airway and check for breathing for at least 5 and no more than 10 seconds

steps.instruction: If the casualty is not breathing (or not breathing effectively/agonal), position your hands in the centre of the upper chest with shoulders directly over your hands
steps.detail: Keep your elbows locked

steps.instruction: Give 30 compressions — push hard, push fast
steps.detail: Press straight down on the breastbone 5–6 cm (2–2.4 in), allow full recoil, and compress at 100–120/min
steps.tip: Count out loud to keep rhythm

steps.instruction: Open the airway by tilting the head and lifting the chin
Give 2 rescue breaths
steps.detail: Use a barrier device if available; each breath ~1 second, just enough to make the chest rise

steps.instruction: This is one cycle of 30:2 (30 compressions to 2 ventilations) — continue CPR until an AED is applied, the casualty responds, another trained rescuer/EMS takes over, or you are too exhausted
steps.warning: Apply the AED as soon as it arrives

warnings: Do not perform on conscious person
Stop if person starts breathing normally
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately — activate EMS and get an AED as soon as possible

guides.title: CPR for Children

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey
Assess responsiveness
If there is no response, send or call for medical help and an AED if available
steps.detail: If you are alone with no phone, perform 5 cycles of CPR (about 2 minutes), then go for medical help; carry the child with you if possible

steps.instruction: Perform a primary survey
steps.detail: Open the airway and check for breathing for at least 5 and no more than 10 seconds

steps.instruction: If the casualty is not breathing (or not breathing effectively/agonal), position your hands in the centre of the upper chest with shoulders directly over your hands
steps.detail: Keep your elbows locked; use one or two hands depending on the child's size

steps.instruction: Give 30 compressions — push hard, push fast
steps.detail: Compress about 1/3 of chest depth (about 5 cm / 2 in), allow full recoil, and compress at 100–120/min
steps.tip: Count out loud to keep rhythm

steps.instruction: Open the airway by tilting the head and lifting the chin
Give 2 rescue breaths
steps.detail: Use a barrier device if available; give just enough air to make the chest rise

steps.instruction: This is one cycle of 30:2 (30 compressions to 2 ventilations) — continue CPR until an AED is applied, the casualty responds, another rescuer/EMS takes over, or you are too exhausted
steps.warning: Apply the AED as soon as it arrives

warnings: Use one or two hands depending on the child's size
If you are alone with no phone, perform about 2 minutes (5 cycles) of CPR before going for help
Apply an AED as soon as it arrives
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately — activate EMS and get an AED as soon as possible (if alone with no phone: 2 minutes/5 cycles first)

guides.title: Choking Relief (Adult)

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey to ensure safety for you and the casualty
Assess severity — ask 'Are you choking?' and look for inability to speak, cough, or breathe
steps.warning: Call 911 immediately if severe obstruction is suspected

steps.instruction: If the person can cough forcefully, speak, or breathe, encourage them to keep coughing
steps.tip: Seek medical help if mild obstruction lasts more than a few minutes

steps.instruction: If severe obstruction: give up to 5 back blows between the shoulder blades
steps.detail: Support the person while striking with the heel of your hand

steps.instruction: If not cleared, stand behind the person ready to support them if they become unconscious
Make a fist and place it at the belly button level, above the navel and below the ribcage
steps.detail: Align with the hip bones; avoid the lower ribcage and xiphoid

steps.instruction: Grasp the fist with your other hand and deliver 5 quick inward and upward abdominal thrusts
steps.detail: Heimlich maneuver

steps.instruction: Repeat cycles of 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until the object is expelled
steps.warning: Do not give food or drink; continue cycles until effective or the person becomes unconscious

steps.instruction: If the person becomes unconscious, lower them to the ground and call for medical help and an AED
steps.warning: Activate EMS immediately

steps.instruction: Begin chest compressions immediately
After the first 30 compressions, open the mouth and remove any visible object
Attempt 2 rescue breaths; if air does not enter, continue compressions and recheck the mouth before each set of ventilations

warnings: For mild obstruction, do not interfere beyond encouraging coughing
Abdominal thrusts can cause internal injuries — seek medical evaluation afterward
If unconscious, prioritize compressions and airway checks with visible object removal only
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately for severe obstruction or if the person becomes unconscious; obtain an AED

guides.title: Choking (Adult) — Self-Help

steps.instruction: If people are around, get their attention — do not isolate yourself
Try to cough up the object
steps.tip: If you can cough forcefully, keep coughing

steps.instruction: Give yourself abdominal thrusts until you can cough forcefully, breathe, or speak
steps.warning: If you cannot breathe or are becoming weak, call 911 immediately

steps.instruction: If needed, use a solid object (back of a chair, table, or counter edge) to deliver thrusts
steps.detail: Position yourself so the edge is just above your hips

steps.instruction: Press forcefully against the object to produce abdominal thrusts
steps.warning: Stop once breathing returns; seek medical evaluation afterward

warnings: Only remove an object if it is clearly visible and easily reachable
Abdominal thrusts can cause internal injuries — seek medical evaluation afterward
If you become dizzy, weak, or lose consciousness, you may fall — try to stay near others
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately if you cannot breathe/speak/cough, symptoms worsen, or after the object is expelled if you have persistent pain

guides.title: Choking Relief (Child)

steps.instruction: Determine if choking is severe
steps.warning: Can't cry, cough, or speak = severe

steps.instruction: For child aged 1-8: use back blows and chest thrusts
steps.detail: Alternate 5 back blows with 5 chest thrusts

steps.instruction: Position child face-down on your forearm
Give 5 sharp back blows between shoulder blades
Turn child face-up and give 5 chest thrusts
steps.detail: Use 2-3 fingers, press 1-1.5 inches deep

steps.instruction: Repeat cycles of 5 back blows and 5 thrusts until the object is expelled
steps.warning: Call 911 if unsuccessful after 2 minutes

steps.instruction: If the child becomes unconscious, lower to the ground, call for medical help and get an AED
Begin chest compressions immediately
After the first 30 compressions, check the mouth and remove any visible object
Attempt 2 rescue breaths; if air does not go in, continue compressions and inspect the mouth before ventilations

warnings: Do not use abdominal thrusts on children under 1 year
Risk of internal organ damage
If unconscious, prioritize compressions and only remove visible objects
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately if unable to clear airway or at any point the child becomes unconscious

guides.title: Choking Relief (Baby)

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and primary survey
steps.tip: Ensure the baby is safe and responsive

steps.instruction: If the baby can cough forcefully or breathe, let the baby try to cough up the object
steps.tip: If a mild obstruction lasts for more than a few minutes, send for medical help

steps.instruction: Assess if baby cannot cough forcefully, cannot breathe, makes high-pitched noise when trying to breathe, or starts to turn blue
steps.warning: These are signs of severe obstruction — begin back blows and chest thrusts immediately

steps.instruction: Secure the baby between your forearms and turn them face-down
steps.detail: Support the baby securely while performing back blows

steps.instruction: With the baby's head lower than the body, use the heel of your hand to give 5 forceful back blows between the shoulder blades
steps.warning: Apply firm pressure between the shoulder blades

steps.instruction: Turn the baby face-up and give 5 chest thrusts
steps.detail: Use 2 fingers and press 1-1.5 inches deep on the breastbone

steps.instruction: Keep giving back blows and chest thrusts until either the airway is cleared or the baby becomes unconscious
steps.warning: Alternate 5 back blows with 5 chest thrusts in cycles

steps.instruction: If the baby becomes unconscious, send for medical help. Begin chest compressions immediately. After the first 30 compressions, check the mouth. Remove any foreign object you can see. Try to give 2 breaths and continue to give chest compressions and inspecting the mouth before ventilations
steps.warning: Call 911 or activate EMS at once

warnings: Do not use abdominal thrusts on babies under 1 year
Risk of severe internal organ damage in infants
High-pitched noise when breathing and blue skin = severe emergency
If unconscious, prioritize compressions and only remove visible objects
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately if unable to clear airway or at any point the baby becomes unconscious

guides.title: First Aid for Severe External Bleeding

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey, then do a primary survey
steps.tip: Ensure safety for you and the casualty before approaching

steps.instruction: To control severe bleeding, apply direct pressure to the wound
steps.detail: Use a clean cloth or bandage and press firmly

steps.instruction: Place the casualty at rest
steps.detail: Keep them calm and still to minimize blood loss

steps.instruction: Once bleeding is under control, continue the primary survey, looking for other life-threatening injuries
steps.warning: Do not focus only on the visible wound

steps.instruction: Before bandaging the wound, check circulation below the injury. Bandage the dressing in place
steps.detail: Ensure the bandage is secure but not too tight to cut off circulation

steps.instruction: Check the circulation below the injury and compare it with the other side
steps.detail: If circulation is worse than before the injury was bandaged, loosen the bandage just enough to improve circulation if possible
steps.warning: Watch for numbness, tingling, or color changes

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care
steps.detail: If the dressings become blood-soaked, don't remove them — add more dressings and continue pressure. Removing the blood-soaked dressings may disturb blood clots and expose the wound to further contamination
steps.warning: Never remove the first layer of dressing

warnings: Do not remove blood-soaked dressings
Removing dressings disrupts blood clots and risks contamination
Watch for signs of shock
Check circulation regularly below the injury
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately for severe or uncontrollable bleeding
guides.duration: Until bleeding is controlled and EMS arrives

guides.title: First Aid for Shock

steps.instruction: Give first aid for the injury or illness that caused the shock
steps.detail: Address the underlying cause while providing shock treatment

steps.instruction: Reassure the casualty often
steps.detail: Keep them calm and informed about what is happening

steps.instruction: Minimize pain by handling the casualty gently
steps.detail: Avoid unnecessary movement and be very careful when moving them

steps.instruction: Loosen tight clothing at the neck, chest and waist
steps.detail: This improves circulation and breathing

steps.instruction: Keep the casualty warm, but do not overheat
steps.detail: Use jackets, coats or blankets if you have them. Avoid overheating

steps.instruction: Moisten the lips if the casualty complains of thirst
steps.detail: Don't give anything to eat or drink. If medical help is delayed many hours, give small amounts of water or clear fluids to drink — make a note of what was given and when

steps.instruction: Place the casualty in the best position for their condition
steps.detail: Generally, lay them flat with legs elevated 8-12 inches above heart level, unless this causes pain or difficulty breathing

warnings: Do not give food or drink unless absolutely necessary after extended delay
Do not overheat the casualty
Handle the casualty gently to minimize pain
Watch for changes in consciousness and breathing
Shock can develop quickly and be life-threatening
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately - shock is a medical emergency
guides.duration: Until EMS arrives and takes over

guides.title: First Aid for Fainting

steps.instruction: Ensure a supply of fresh air and loosen tight clothing
steps.detail: Loosen tight clothing at the neck, chest and waist to improve breathing

steps.instruction: Make the casualty comfortable as consciousness returns
steps.detail: Keep them lying down for 10 to 15 minutes

steps.instruction: Continue to monitor breathing and consciousness
steps.detail: Watch for any changes in their condition

steps.instruction: If recovery is not quick or complete, stay with the casualty
steps.detail: Do not assume a person has 'just fainted' unless there is a quick recovery. Stay with them until medical help takes over

steps.instruction: If you must leave, turn the casualty into the recovery position
steps.detail: Be as careful as you can if there are any injuries

warnings: Do not assume quick recovery without monitoring
Do not leave the casualty unattended if recovery seems incomplete
If fainting is caused by another condition, treat the underlying cause
Watch for changes in breathing or consciousness
guides.whenToCall911: If recovery is not quick/complete, or if fainting is due to injury, chest pain, or repeat fainting

guides.title: First Aid for Impending Faint

steps.instruction: Place the casualty on their back
steps.detail: Do this as soon as you recognize the warning signs

steps.instruction: Ensure a supply of fresh air
steps.detail: Open windows or doors to provide ventilation

steps.instruction: Loosen tight clothing at the neck, chest and waist
steps.detail: This improves circulation and breathing

steps.instruction: Stay with the casualty until they have fully recovered
steps.detail: Monitor their condition and be ready to provide further assistance

warnings: Warning signs include: pale skin, sweating, feeling sick or nauseous, dizziness, or unsteadiness
Act quickly when you notice these signs to prevent actual fainting
Do not leave the casualty unattended during recovery
guides.whenToCall911: If the casualty loses consciousness or does not recover quickly
guides.duration: Until full recovery, usually a few minutes

guides.title: First Degree Burns (Minor)

steps.instruction: Cool the burn
steps.detail: Hold the area under cool — not cold — running water for about 10 minutes. If this isn't possible or if the burn is on the face, apply a cool, wet cloth until the pain eases. For a mouth burn from hot food or drink, put a piece of ice in the mouth for a few minutes

steps.instruction: Remove rings or other tight items
steps.detail: Try to do this quickly and gently, before the burned area swells

steps.instruction: Apply lotion
steps.detail: After the burn is cooled, apply a lotion, such as one with aloe vera or cocoa butter. This helps prevent drying

steps.instruction: Bandage the burn
steps.detail: Cover the burn with a clean bandage. Wrap it loosely to avoid putting pressure on burned skin. Bandaging keeps air off the area, reduces pain and protects blistered skin

steps.instruction: If needed, take a nonprescription pain reliever
steps.detail: Such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others)
steps.tip: Pain relievers can reduce inflammation and discomfort

warnings: Do not apply ice directly to skin
Do not use butter or oily substances
Do not break blisters if they form
guides.whenToCall911: Not necessary for minor burns

guides.title: First Aid for a Second-Degree Burn

steps.instruction: Place the burn under cool running water for at least 5 minutes
steps.detail: Use cool water, not cold water

steps.instruction: Remove all excess clothing and accessories from around the burned area
steps.detail: Do this carefully to avoid further damage

steps.instruction: Take an over-the-counter pain reliever
steps.detail: Such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to manage pain

steps.instruction: Drink plenty of fluids
steps.detail: This helps prevent dehydration from the burn injury

steps.instruction: Seek medical attention if needed
steps.warning: Consult a healthcare provider, especially for large burns or burns on sensitive areas

warnings: Do not ice the burn as this can further damage the skin
Do not break the blisters
Never put butter on a burn
Avoid wrapping the burn tightly with gauze as this can put pressure on the burn tissue
guides.whenToCall911: For burns larger than 3 inches, burns on face/joints/genitals, or if unable to manage pain

guides.title: Third Degree Burns (Severe)

steps.instruction: Call 911 IMMEDIATELY - this is a medical emergency
steps.warning: Do not delay emergency services

steps.instruction: Remove from heat source and heat source
steps.detail: Do not cool with water - risk of shock

steps.instruction: Do NOT remove stuck clothing or jewelry
steps.warning: Removing causes additional tissue damage

steps.instruction: Lay person flat with burned area elevated
steps.detail: Elevate above heart to reduce shock

steps.instruction: Cover with clean, dry cloth only
steps.warning: Do not apply ointments, ice, or water

steps.instruction: Monitor for shock - keep person warm
steps.detail: Cover with blanket but not over burn

steps.instruction: Do not give anything to eat or drink
steps.warning: May need anesthesia for surgery

warnings: Charred, white, or leathery appearance
Little to no pain (nerves destroyed)
Life-threatening burns - major medical emergency
Risk of severe infection, shock, and death
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately

guides.title: Treat Shock

steps.instruction: Call 911 immediately
steps.warning: Shock is life-threatening

steps.instruction: Identify cause of shock if possible
steps.detail: Severe injury, blood loss, severe illness, allergic reaction

steps.instruction: Lay person flat with legs elevated 12 inches
steps.detail: Unless head injury or spinal injury suspected

steps.instruction: Keep person warm with blankets
Do not give food or water
steps.warning: May choke or vomit

steps.instruction: Monitor breathing and pulse
steps.detail: Be prepared to begin CPR

steps.instruction: Reassure person and keep them calm
steps.tip: Emotional support helps reduce shock severity

warnings: Signs: pale, cold, clammy skin, weakness, rapid/weak pulse
Can be fatal if untreated
Monitor continuously until help arrives
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately

guides.title: First Aid for a Severe Allergic Reaction

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and a primary survey. Send for medical help
steps.warning: Call 911 immediately for severe reactions

steps.instruction: Place the casualty in the most comfortable position for breathing
steps.detail: Usually sitting upright. This position helps open the airway

steps.instruction: Assist the casualty with their medication, usually an epinephrine auto-injector
steps.detail: Help them use their EpiPen or similar auto-injector as directed

steps.instruction: To use the auto-injector: Remove from storage tube and hold firmly with orange tip downward
steps.detail: Remove the blue safety release

steps.instruction: Use the auto-injector on the fleshy part of the mid-outer thigh
steps.detail: Auto-injectors can be given through lightweight clothing

steps.instruction: Press the orange tip firmly into the mid-outer thigh until the unit activates
steps.detail: The injection will deliver the epinephrine automatically

steps.instruction: Hold the auto-injector in place for several seconds, then pull it straight out
steps.detail: Ensure the full dose has been delivered

steps.instruction: After injection, keep the casualty warm and avoid any exertion
steps.warning: Call 911 as soon as you have given the first dose

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care
steps.detail: Monitor breathing and vital signs, be prepared for CPR if needed

warnings: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening emergency
Symptoms include: difficulty breathing, throat tightness, swelling, hives, dizziness
Call 911 immediately for severe reactions
Use EpiPen as soon as anaphylaxis is suspected
Call 911 as soon as the first dose is given
Symptoms may recur - seek immediate medical attention
Do not elevate legs if difficulty breathing
Do not re-insert the needle back into the auto-injector after use
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately for severe allergic reactions or anaphylaxis

guides.title: General First Aid for Poisoning

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and a primary survey
steps.detail: Gather any information about the suspected poison

steps.instruction: If the casualty is responsive, call the Poison Information Centre
steps.detail: Follow their advice carefully. They will guide treatment based on the specific poison

steps.instruction: If the casualty is unresponsive or having a seizure, call for medical help
steps.warning: Call 911 immediately

steps.instruction: If the casualty is unresponsive but breathing, place in the recovery position
steps.detail: Keep airway open and monitor breathing

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care until medical help takes over
steps.detail: Monitor vital signs, keep them warm, and be prepared for CPR

warnings: Do not induce vomiting unless advised by Poison Information Centre
Do not dilute swallowed poisons unless told to by Poison Information Centre
For inhaled poisons, ensure your own safety before helping
Assess hazards with attention to poisonous gas or vapour
For absorbed poisons, flush with large amounts of cool water
For injected poisons, keep affected limb below heart level
Time is critical with poisoning
Many poisons cause delayed symptoms
guides.whenToCall911: If unresponsive, having seizures, or if Poison Information Centre advises

guides.title: First Aid for Swallowed Poisons

steps.instruction: If CPR is required, check the area around the mouth
steps.detail: Wipe clear any poisonous residue. Always use a barrier device for added protection

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and a primary survey
steps.detail: Assess responsiveness and breathing

steps.instruction: Do not dilute the poison by giving fluids
steps.warning: Unless specifically told to do so by the Poison Information Centre

steps.instruction: If conscious, wipe poisonous or corrosive residue from the face
steps.detail: Rinse or wipe out the mouth carefully

steps.instruction: Never induce vomiting except on advice of Poison Information Centre
steps.warning: Many poisons cause more damage when vomited

warnings: Do not dilute without Poison Information Centre advice
Do not induce vomiting without Poison Information Centre advice
Many corrosive poisons will damage the mouth and throat if vomited
Always protect yourself with barrier device if giving CPR
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately - call Poison Information Centre

guides.title: First Aid for Inhaled Poisons

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and a primary survey
steps.detail: Assess hazards with particular attention to the possible presence of a poisonous gas or vapour. Ensure your safety; it may be best to wait for professional rescuers

steps.instruction: Move the person to fresh air and away from the source
steps.warning: Only do this if it is safe for you to do so

steps.instruction: If breathing is not present, begin CPR
steps.detail: If the poison could affect you while giving first aid, use a face mask or shield with a one-way valve

steps.instruction: If the casualty vomits, keep the airway open
steps.detail: Clear out the mouth and put the casualty into the recovery position

steps.instruction: If the casualty goes into convulsions, prevent injury
steps.detail: Protect them from striking objects

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care and get medical help
steps.detail: Monitor breathing and consciousness

warnings: Ensure your own safety before helping - do not enter hazardous areas
Use protective equipment (mask, shield) if available
Move to fresh air immediately
Watch for delayed respiratory symptoms
Be prepared for vomiting or seizures
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately

guides.title: First Aid for Absorbed Poisons

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and a primary survey
steps.detail: Assess the situation and extent of exposure

steps.instruction: Flush the affected area with large amounts of cool water
steps.detail: If the poisonous substance is a powder, brush off excessive amounts with a dry cloth before flushing

steps.instruction: Remove any clothing that has been in contact with the poison
steps.warning: Don't touch the clothing until it has been thoroughly washed

steps.instruction: Wash the affected skin thoroughly with soap and water
steps.detail: Continue washing for several minutes

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care until medical help takes over
steps.detail: Monitor for signs of systemic absorption and seek medical attention

warnings: Some chemicals absorbed through skin can cause life-threatening emergencies
Brush off powder before flushing to avoid spreading
Do not touch contaminated clothing with bare hands
Watch for symptoms of systemic poisoning even after initial treatment
Contact dermatitis includes redness, itching and blisters
guides.whenToCall911: If signs of systemic poisoning or large area affected
guides.duration: Continuous flushing for at least 10-15 minutes

guides.title: First Aid for Injected Poisons

steps.instruction: Follow general first aid for poisoning
steps.detail: Perform scene and primary survey, call for help if needed

steps.instruction: Place the casualty at rest
steps.detail: Keep the affected limb below heart level to slow poison circulation

steps.instruction: Immobilize the affected limb
steps.detail: This delays the circulation of the poison throughout the body

steps.instruction: If needle-stick with possible disease contamination, scrub vigorously
steps.detail: Use Iodine or similar disinfectant at the injection site

steps.instruction: Get medical attention
steps.warning: Injected poisons require professional medical evaluation and treatment

warnings: Keep affected limb immobilized and below heart level
Do not move the affected limb more than necessary
For needle-stick injuries, seek immediate medical attention
Systemic symptoms may be delayed
Always get professional medical evaluation
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately for significant injections or unknown sources

guides.title: First Aid for a Seizure or Convulsion

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey. Make the area safe
steps.detail: Clear away objects that could cause injury. Clear onlookers away to ensure the casualty's privacy

steps.instruction: During convulsions, do not restrict the casualty's movements
steps.detail: Protect them from injury. Carefully loosen tight clothing, especially around the neck. Place something soft under the head

steps.instruction: Do not try to put anything in the mouth
steps.warning: Do not try to put anything between the teeth or to hold the tongue

steps.instruction: Perform a primary survey after convulsions are finished
steps.detail: Check for breathing and responsiveness

steps.instruction: Place the unconscious casualty into the recovery position
steps.detail: Clear any fluids from the mouth or nose

steps.instruction: Do a secondary survey to check for injuries
steps.detail: See if the casualty was injured during the seizure; give first aid for any injuries found

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care
steps.detail: Monitor breathing, keep the casualty warm and allow them to rest

steps.instruction: Don't give the casualty any liquids during or immediately after a seizure
steps.warning: Risk of choking or aspiration

warnings: Do not restrict movements during convulsion
Do not put anything in the mouth
Call 911 if unconscious for more than 5 minutes
Call 911 if there is a second major seizure within a few minutes
Call 911 if this is the person's first seizure or cause is unknown
Protect casualty from striking objects or walls
Do not give food or liquids immediately after seizure
guides.whenToCall911: If unconscious >5 minutes, second seizure within minutes, first seizure, or unknown cause
guides.duration: Until casualty regains consciousness and is stable

guides.title: First Aid for a Severe Asthma Attack

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey and a primary survey; send for medical help
steps.detail: Call 911 or emergency services immediately for a severe attack

steps.instruction: Place the casualty in the most comfortable position for breathing
steps.detail: This is usually sitting upright with arms resting on a table

steps.instruction: Help the casualty take prescribed medication
steps.detail: Assist them with their rescue inhaler or prescribed asthma medications

steps.instruction: Give ongoing casualty care
steps.detail: Monitor breathing and consciousness, keep them calm and reassured

steps.instruction: If the unconscious casualty stops breathing, begin CPR
steps.warning: Be prepared to perform CPR if necessary

warnings: Severe asthma attacks can be life-threatening
Do not delay calling 911 for a severe attack
Watch for signs of respiratory distress or unconsciousness
Do not restrict casualty's movement or panic them
Have their rescue inhaler ready immediately
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately for severe asthma attacks

guides.title: Assisting with a Metered Dose Inhaler

steps.instruction: Shake the container, then remove the cap
steps.detail: Prepare the metered dose inhaler (MDI or 'puffer') for use

steps.instruction: Tell the casualty to breathe out completely
steps.detail: Empty their lungs of air before inhaling the medication

steps.instruction: Tell the casualty to breathe in slowly and deeply
steps.detail: As the casualty does, press the MDI to release the medication. The MDI can be in the mouth, or just in front of the mouth

steps.instruction: Tell the casualty to hold their breath for 10 seconds
steps.detail: This allows the medication to spread out in the lungs. Then tell them to breathe normally so the medication won't be expelled. If more doses are needed, wait at least 30-60 seconds before repeating these steps

warnings: Follow the casualty's prescribed instructions for their specific inhaler
Some inhalers require a spacer device for proper delivery
Do not shake the inhaler while the casualty is inhaling
Make sure the casualty understands the technique
If symptoms don't improve after 15 minutes, seek medical help
guides.whenToCall911: If asthma attack symptoms worsen or don't improve after medication use

guides.title: First Aid for Angina/Heart Attack

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey, then do a primary survey
steps.detail: Ask the casualty questions: 'Can you show me where it hurts?' 'Have you had this pain before?' 'Do you have medication for this pain?'

steps.instruction: Call for medical help and get a defibrillator
steps.warning: Call 911 immediately - time is critical

steps.instruction: Place the casualty at rest in the semi-sitting position
steps.detail: The semi-sitting position is usually the best option, and reassure them

steps.instruction: Assist the conscious casualty to take their prescribed medication
steps.detail: Usually nitroglycerin. If the casualty has no prescribed medication, or the first dose is ineffective, ask if they have any allergies to ASA, or if a doctor has told them not to take it. If the casualty believes they can take it, suggest they chew one regular ASA tablet (or two low-dose tablets). ASA can reduce the effects of a heart attack because of its anti-clotting properties

steps.instruction: If the casualty loses consciousness and stops breathing, start CPR
steps.warning: Be prepared to perform CPR immediately

warnings: Chest pain, pressure, or heaviness requires immediate medical attention
Pain may radiate to arm, jaw, or back
Ask about allergies to ASA before administering
Women may have atypical symptoms
Call 911 immediately - every minute counts
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately

guides.title: First Aid for Stroke/TIA

steps.instruction: Perform a scene survey, then do a primary survey; perform the FAST assessment
steps.detail: F.A.S.T. = Face drooping, Arms weakness, Speech difficulty, Time of onset. Check for these signs immediately

steps.instruction: Call for medical help
steps.warning: Call 911 immediately - time is critical, treatment must start within hours

steps.instruction: Place the casualty at rest in the semi-sitting position
steps.detail: This position helps with breathing and circulation

steps.instruction: Give nothing by mouth, especially ASA
steps.warning: The casualty may have difficulty swallowing and ASA is contraindicated in some stroke types

steps.instruction: Give ongoing care
steps.detail: Monitor breathing and consciousness, keep them calm and reassured, and be prepared for CPR if needed

warnings: Face drooping on one side
Arm weakness or numbness on one side
Speech difficulty or slurring
Vision problems or loss
Loss of balance or dizziness
Severe headache with no known cause
Do not give food or water - risk of choking
Do not give ASA - may worsen some stroke types
Minutes = brain cells dying - act FAST
guides.whenToCall911: Immediately at first sign of stroke symptoms
